addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England

6 Sep
t
1592. M
r
Bodeley. to my L. from
e Hagh/

page.lettertext:
fol.226r
May it please yo
r
good L. I send w
t
this letter
the Answear of
e
states:
w
ch
is dated
e 4 and
was
e time
at they resolved, but their letter
was written, and brought me but to day. What
passed between us, when I made my Proposition,
I have written to yo
r
L.
e 5 of this moneth, and
I send againe, for more assurance, bothe
e copie of
my letter and
at whiche I proposed. Astouching
the companies I did never looke for other answear.
But although they will not yelde to any licence di-
rectly; I hope indirectly they will wincke at their
passage. They were alwaies determined to
send suche forces into
Britaine,
as I have signified
heeretofore: but w
t
condition
at her
Ma
tie
would
make an offer in proportion, to doe as muche as
they required: w
ch
I advertised lately
e 16 of
July. Nowe their offer is framed in an other de-
gree, as yo
r
L. may perceave. To her
Ma
ties
demaunde for further succo
r
to be sent to
e
garrison of
Ostend,
in respect of those attemptes
w
ch
are supposed to be intended against
e towne
and
e haven, they touche it onely in a worde, as
they doe in their speeches make light of
e mater.
For they say they are assured,
at
e Enemie in
those quarters hath no meanes to raise forces, to put
e towne in any danger. And yet there is lately
order given, for 6 shippes more then were before,
(w
ch
were alwaies 12) to lie upon
e coast.
Heere are letters from
e Campe
at
e Enemie is
departed from
e quarters of
Coevoerden,
and is
marched towardes
Groeninghen,
to assure
e passa-
ges; and towardes
Linghen,
w
ch
is a place of speciall
strength in
e Countie of Benthem, southerly from
fol.226v
Coevoerden, about 6 Dutche leagues. If it falle out
to be true, as we doubt not of it, what
Count Mau-
rice
will doe, it is not yet knowen: but I make
full account
at
S
r
Francis Vere
will returne w
t
all
e speede
at may be. Yesterday
M
r
Caron
had some occasion to deale w
t
e general states,
and opportunitie serving to speake about
e Companies,
he hath said as muche unto them, to persuade them to
yelde, as he supposed might be said w
t
out their offense.
But yet he praieth me to signifie,
at against his
exp ect ation, and
at w
ch
was his hope, in his last to
yo
r
L. he doth finde they will doe nothing. I doe
mervel very muche
at he would give yo
w
any hope,
of their assenting therunto. It was to measure their
forwardnes, by his owne disposition. For otherwise
me thinkes, there is very muche gotten, considering
their humo
rs
, though they should not assent, if they
would but lette them goe, by way of permission.
And that I hope we shall obtene,
at though they be
thus unwilling, they will not practise any meanes,
to stoppe their embarking. After
e re-
ceat of this Answear of
e states, her Ma
ties
letter
of
e 27 of Au
g
is brought unto me: wherein I
am required to send for
S
r
John Poley
and
S
r
Nicholas
Parker
, and after notice given unto them of her
Hig
nes
intent, to be served w
t
one of their bandes,
for
e succo
r
of
e footemen
at are appointed for
France,
to make choise of
e fittest of them bothe,
w
t
e advise of S
r
Francis Vere: if too muche time
be not lost by sending unto him. It may
please yo
r
L. to consider,
at before my letters can
come to
e forsaid gentlemen, at
e Campe where they
are, I must of necessitie, all thinges considered,
recken upon 4 daies, and upon as many for them
to come
fol.227r
to come to
e Hage, and so againe as many more to
returne unto their companies: besides
e time
at
will be spent in other usual pretenses. In w
ch
respect
and for
e speedier perfourmance of her Ma
ties
purpose,
having alwaies understoode,
at no man hath kept
his bande in so good plight and discipline, aswell
for order, as nomber, and furniture, as S
r
Nicholas Par-
ker, I have thought it most convenient, for better
expedition, to send directly unto him, and in his ab-
sence (for
at I stand in some doubt he is not at
e campe)
to his Lieutenant, who is a very sufficient souldier,
to prepare his troupe in suche sort, as her Ma
tie
hath
commaunded, and to supplie his deficients out of
S
r
John Poleis company. To whome I have also signified
w
at
is written from her Ma
tie
doubting nothing
ether, but
at they will be very ready, to conforme
themselves accordingly. And albeit by her Ma
tie
I am not willed to impart this matter to
e states,
yet because it is requisit in regard of correspon-
dence, I will acquaint them w
t
it presently, ex-
pecting notw
t
standing for no good answear at their
handes. But whatsoever it is, I have sent a mes-
senger
already
to advertise
e pleasure of her Ma
tie
to S
r
Nicholas
Parker, and
e like to S
r
Francis Vere, to
e end
at
being there, he may give his assistance, as neede
shall require. Even nowe I am req
e
sted
to convey a letter of S
r
Francis Vere to yo
r
L.
and I am told
by
e partie
at hath brought me
e
letter,
at S
r
Francis for certaine was comming
from
e campe, and did resolve to be at
Swol
e
5 of this moneth, w
t
intention to come forward
w
t
his troupes towardes
Zeland.
I knowe
not what to thinke, howe
e states will supplie
e
garrison of
Berghen.
For they of themselves will
fol.227v
tell me nothing, though I presse them very often:
because in shewe they will not seeme, not onely not
to be contented, but not to be persuaded
at her Ma
tie
will drawe
e companies from hens: wheras by
naming
e troupes,
at they minde to send for supply,
they should seeme to insinuat, as if they were cont
e
ted
to send others in their places. I would make
some motion to yo
r
L. for hastening
e c
o
panies
at should come out of France for
Flushing
and
e
Brille, but
at I knowe it is needeles for w
ch
I
take my humble leave.
At
e Hage
Sep
t
6

t
6
1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
